title: How to Make Gingerbread Cake

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).
Prepare a 9 inch (22.86 centimeters) baking pan.
steps.description: Grease the inside of the baking pan, then dust it with flour. Shake out any excess flour. You can use a round or square baking pan for this.

steps.headline: Beat together the sugar and butter until they are light and fluffy.
steps.description: To get a smoother consistency, beat the butter first, then slowly mix in the sugar. Try using an electric mixer for this; it will be faster.

steps.headline: Add in the egg and the molasses.
steps.description: Keep mixing until you get a smooth texture and an even color.

steps.headline: Combine the rest of your dry ingredients in another bowl.
steps.description: Pour the flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, ginger, and cloves into a large bowl. Mix them together until everything is evenly dispersed.

steps.headline: Mix the dry ingredients with the molasses-butter mixture.
steps.description: Pour the spiced flour mixture into the molasses-butter mixture. While you are pouring, stir everything together with a whisk or spatula. If you are using an electric mixer for this step, you might want to reduce the speed to the lowest setting possible so that the flour does not fly out everywhere.

steps.headline: Stir in the hot water.
steps.description: Keep mixing until everything is smooth.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into the baking pan.
steps.description: Start at one end of the pan and slowly move your way down to the other. If necessary, use a spatula to help guide the batter to the edges. Be careful not to scrape the bottom or sides of the pan.

steps.headline: Bake for an hour or until a pick is inserted and comes out clean.
steps.description: Avoid peeking into the oven. Each time you open the oven, you release heat. This will affect the baking time.

steps.headline: Let the cake cool before taking it out of the pan and decorating it.
steps.description: You can decorate your cake however you want, but you might want to wait until it cools off completely before you do so. If you decorate your cake too soon, the frosting will melt and slide right off. For frosting, icing, and garnish recipes, click here. For decorating ideas, click here.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 375°F (190.56°C) and prepare a 15 by 10 inch (38.1 by 25.4 centimeters) jelly roll pan.
steps.description: Line the bottom of the pan with parchment paper. Then, grease the pan and the parchment paper. Finish off by dusting flour over the grease. Set the pan aside.

steps.headline: Beat three egg yolks until they are thickened.
steps.description: Separate the egg yolks from the egg whites. Beat them for about 3 minutes. You can use a handheld mixer or a food processor with a whisk attachment. The egg yolks need to be thick and creamy.

steps.headline: Mix molasses, honey, and melted butter into the beaten egg yolk.
steps.description: If you want a darker gingerbread, omit the honey and use ½ cup (165 grams) molasses. If you want a lighter gingerbread, omit the molasses and use ½ cup (175 grams) honey.

steps.headline: Beat the 3 egg whites until they turn white, foamy, and peaky.
steps.description: Put the egg whites into a clean mixing bowl. Beat them until they turn white and stiff. They egg whites are ready when they turn white, become stiff, and get soft peaks. You can use a handheld mixer or a food processor with a whisk attachment to beat them.

steps.headline: Add the sugar into the beaten egg whites slowly.
steps.description: Keep mixing until you get firm peaks.

steps.headline: Fold the egg whites mixture into the egg yolks mixture.
steps.description: Use a spatula to guide the egg whites mixture into the egg yolks mixture a little bit at a time. Stir the two mixtures together using a rolling motion, starting from the bottom of the bowl and moving upwards. This will help trap some air bubbles inside the batter.

steps.headline: Sift in the flour, baking soda, salt, and spices.
steps.description: Stir slowly so that you don't lose the air bubbles. Try to use that same horizontal stirring motion as before.

steps.headline: Spread the mixture over the baking pan.
steps.description: Start at one end of the pan and slowly work your way towards the other. If needed, move the mixing bowl back and forth in a wave-like motion. The batter needs to spread over the entire pan. It will be thin, which is normal; you will be rolling the baked gingerbread into a roll later.

steps.headline: Bake the cake for 11 minutes or until the top is springy, then let it cool for 3 minutes.
steps.description: Take it out of the oven once the time is up, and leave it some place where it will not be disturbed.

steps.headline: Turn the cake onto a damp tea towel dusted with confectioners/icing sugar.
steps.description: Dampen a tea towel and sprinkle confectioners/icing sugar all over it. Place the cake upside-down onto the tea towel and lift the pan away. Peel off the parchment paper and discard it.

steps.headline: Roll the cake up like a cinnamon roll.
steps.description: Start at one end, and begin rolling the cake into a tube. Some people find it easiest to roll the cake along with the tea towel. You will be unrolling it later.

steps.headline: Let the cake finish cooling while you prepare the filling.
steps.description: To make the filling, combine the heavy cream, sugar, and cinnamon in a mixing bowl. Whisk together until your get firm peaks. Start at a slow speed before increasing to a higher one.

steps.headline: Unroll the cake, remove the tea towel, and spread two-thirds of your filling over the top.
steps.description: Make sure that the cake is completely cool before you start filling it. Once it is cool, use a spatula to spread the filling over the top. Start from the center, and spread the filling all the way to the edges. Remember to leave some of the filling for the outside of the cake.

steps.headline: Re-roll the cake and finish spreading the rest of the filling over it.
steps.description: Use the spatula to spread the filling over the top and sides of the cake. You can cover the two flat ends, or your can leave them uncovered; the spiral can look nice. For some added color: dust some ground cinnamon over the top of the cake. If you left a bumpy texture with the frosting, this can make your cake look like a Yule log. For some added flavor: sprinkle some lemon zest, orange zest, candied orange peel, or candied ginger over the top of your frosted cake. For some added design: make some sugared cranberries and arrange them on top of your cake. Add some mint leaves to make them look like holly.

steps.headline: Consider making some icing or buttercream for your gingerbread.
steps.description: Gingerbread cake can be tasty on its own, but you can make it even tastier by adding some icing or buttercream. This section will show you a few simple recipes.

steps.headline: Try a lemon glacé icing.
steps.description: Add ½ cup (65 grams) plus and additional 2 tablespoons of confectioners/icing sugar into a small bowl. Slowly pour in 1 tablespoon of warm water while mixing briskly with a whisk. Once the mixture thickens and turns syrupy, mix in 1 tablespoon of lemon juice. For additional flavor, add in some lemon zest. Drizzle this icing over the top of your cake. Consider sprinkling some lemon zest over the top of the icing.

steps.headline: Try an orange glacé icing.
steps.description: Combine 5 ounces (150 grams) of confectioners/icing sugar and 2 tablespoons of fresh-squeezed orange juice in a bowl. Mix briskly with a small whisk until you get a thick, syrupy mixture. If you want your glaze to be thinner, add some more orange juice. For additional flavor, add some orange zest. Drizzle the icing over the top of the cake. Consider sprinkling some orange zest over the icing.

steps.headline: Try a spiced buttercream.
steps.description: In a mixing bowl, combine ¼ cup (55 grams) granulated sugar, ¼ cup (30 grams) confectioners/icing sugar, 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon, and ¼ teaspoon ground cloves. Set it aside. In a separate bowl, beat 2 cups (475 milliliters) whipping/heavy cream until stiff peaks form. Slowly mix in the sugar mixture and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract until you get a smooth color and consistency. Spread the buttercream over the cake once the cake cools. You can spread it over the top and the sides, or just the top.

steps.headline: Try a cream cheese buttercream.
steps.description: In a mixing bowl, beat together 6 ounces (170 grams) of softened cream cheese and 1/3 cup (75 grams) of softened, unsalted butter. Slowly mix in 1¾ cups (220 grams) of confectioners/icing sugar and ½ teaspoon of vanilla extract. Keep mixing until the buttercream is light and fluffy. You can spread the buttercream over the top and the sides of your cake, or just the top. Consider sprinkling some candied orange peel, orange zest, or candied ginger bits over the buttercream once you are done.

steps.headline: Consider making some sugared cranberries.
steps.description: Rinse and dry your cranberries, then coat them with a mixture made from 2 teaspoons of agave nectar and 1 teaspoon of water. Toss the berries in a bowl filled with ¼ cup (50 grams) granulated sugar. Gently lift the sugar-coated berries out of the bowl and let them dry on a sheet of parchment paper for 1 hour.

steps.headline: Make sure that the cake is completely cool before you start decorating it.
steps.description: If you decorate it too soon, the icing will melt and slide right off. Also, a warm cake is a fragile cake. If you try to handle it too soon, it may fall apart. Listed below are several decorating ideas.

steps.headline: Spread some buttercream over the top of the cake.
steps.description: For a richer cake, spread more buttercream down the sides. Use a spatula, palette knife, or butter knife to do this. Start spreading from the center outwards. You can make the frosting as smooth or as textured as you'd like.

steps.headline: Fill the cake with buttercream or jam.
steps.description: Slice the cake in half horizontally. Spread some buttercream or over the bottom layer. Start from the center and work your way towards the ends. When you are done, place the upper layer on top. You can then spread more buttercream over the top and sides or the cake, or drizzle some glacé icing over it.

steps.headline: Pour some glacé icing over the top of the cake.
steps.description: For some added color and flavor, sprinkle some lemon zest, orange zest, candied orange peel, or candied ginger over the top of your frosted cake.

steps.headline: Make some sugared cranberries and arrange them on top of your cake.
steps.description:
Cover your cake with thick, buttercream frosting first. Then, arrange the sugared cranberries however you want on top. To make the berries look like holly, add some mint leaves. Here is one decorating idea:
After you have frosted your cake, three berries in the center. Arrange rest all around the edges of the cake. Place two to three mint leaves around the three center berries.

steps.headline: Add some mini gingerbread men on top of the cake.
steps.description: Begin by frosting your cake with a thick layer of buttercream. Make or buy some 1 to 2 inch (2.54 to 5.08 centimeters) tall gingerbread men. Stick them on top of a cake, right into the frosting. You can use plain gingerbread men, or decorate them with piped icing ahead of time.

steps.headline: Finished.

text:
Basic Gingerbread Cake Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).  Prepare a 9 inch (22.86 centimeters) baking pan. Grease the inside of the baking pan, then dust it with flour. Shake out any excess flour. You can use a round or square baking pan for this. Beat together the sugar and butter until they are light and fluffy. To get a smoother consistency, beat the butter first, then slowly mix in the sugar. Try using an electric mixer for this; it will be faster. Add in the egg and the molasses. Keep mixing until you get a smooth texture and an even color. Combine the rest of your dry ingredients in another bowl. Pour the flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, ginger, and cloves into a large bowl. Mix them together until everything is evenly dispersed. Mix the dry ingredients with the molasses-butter mixture. Pour the spiced flour mixture into the molasses-butter mixture. While you are pouring, stir everything together with a whisk or spatula. If you are using an electric mixer for this step, you might want to reduce the speed to the lowest setting possible so that the flour does not fly out everywhere. Stir in the hot water. Keep mixing until everything is smooth. Pour the mixture into the baking pan. Start at one end of the pan and slowly move your way down to the other. If necessary, use a spatula to help guide the batter to the edges. Be careful not to scrape the bottom or sides of the pan. Bake for an hour or until a pick is inserted and comes out clean. Avoid peeking into the oven. Each time you open the oven, you release heat. This will affect the baking time. Let the cake cool before taking it out of the pan and decorating it. You can decorate your cake however you want, but you might want to wait until it cools off completely before you do so. If you decorate your cake too soon, the frosting will melt and slide right off. For frosting, icing, and garnish recipes, click here. For decorating ideas, click here. Rolled Gingerbread Cake Preheat the oven to 375°F (190.56°C) and prepare a 15 by 10 inch (38.1 by 25.4 centimeters) jelly roll pan. Line the bottom of the pan with parchment paper. Then, grease the pan and the parchment paper. Finish off by dusting flour over the grease. Set the pan aside. Beat three egg yolks until they are thickened. Separate the egg yolks from the egg whites. Beat them for about 3 minutes. You can use a handheld mixer or a food processor with a whisk attachment. The egg yolks need to be thick and creamy. Mix molasses, honey, and melted butter into the beaten egg yolk. If you want a darker gingerbread, omit the honey and use ½ cup (165 grams) molasses. If you want a lighter gingerbread, omit the molasses and use ½ cup (175 grams) honey. Beat the 3 egg whites until they turn white, foamy, and peaky. Put the egg whites into a clean mixing bowl. Beat them until they turn white and stiff. They egg whites are ready when they turn white, become stiff, and get soft peaks. You can use a handheld mixer or a food processor with a whisk attachment to beat them. Add the sugar into the beaten egg whites slowly. Keep mixing until you get firm peaks. Fold the egg whites mixture into the egg yolks mixture. Use a spatula to guide the egg whites mixture into the egg yolks mixture a little bit at a time. Stir the two mixtures together using a rolling motion, starting from the bottom of the bowl and moving upwards. This will help trap some air bubbles inside the batter. Sift in the flour, baking soda, salt, and spices. Stir slowly so that you don't lose the air bubbles. Try to use that same horizontal stirring motion as before. Spread the mixture over the baking pan. Start at one end of the pan and slowly work your way towards the other. If needed, move the mixing bowl back and forth in a wave-like motion. The batter needs to spread over the entire pan. It will be thin, which is normal; you will be rolling the baked gingerbread into a roll later. Bake the cake for 11 minutes or until the top is springy, then let it cool for 3 minutes. Take it out of the oven once the time is up, and leave it some place where it will not be disturbed. Turn the cake onto a damp tea towel dusted with confectioners/icing sugar. Dampen a tea towel and sprinkle confectioners/icing sugar all over it. Place the cake upside-down onto the tea towel and lift the pan away. Peel off the parchment paper and discard it. Roll the cake up like a cinnamon roll. Start at one end, and begin rolling the cake into a tube. Some people find it easiest to roll the cake along with the tea towel. You will be unrolling it later. Let the cake finish cooling while you prepare the filling. To make the filling, combine the heavy cream, sugar, and cinnamon in a mixing bowl. Whisk together until your get firm peaks. Start at a slow speed before increasing to a higher one. Unroll the cake, remove the tea towel, and spread two-thirds of your filling over the top. Make sure that the cake is completely cool before you start filling it. Once it is cool, use a spatula to spread the filling over the top. Start from the center, and spread the filling all the way to the edges. Remember to leave some of the filling for the outside of the cake. Re-roll the cake and finish spreading the rest of the filling over it. Use the spatula to spread the filling over the top and sides of the cake. You can cover the two flat ends, or your can leave them uncovered; the spiral can look nice. For some added color: dust some ground cinnamon over the top of the cake. If you left a bumpy texture with the frosting, this can make your cake look like a Yule log. For some added flavor: sprinkle some lemon zest, orange zest, candied orange peel, or candied ginger over the top of your frosted cake. For some added design: make some sugared cranberries and arrange them on top of your cake. Add some mint leaves to make them look like holly. Making the Icing and Garnish Consider making some icing or buttercream for your gingerbread. Gingerbread cake can be tasty on its own, but you can make it even tastier by adding some icing or buttercream. This section will show you a few simple recipes. Try a lemon glacé icing. Add ½ cup (65 grams) plus and additional 2 tablespoons of confectioners/icing sugar into a small bowl. Slowly pour in 1 tablespoon of warm water while mixing briskly with a whisk. Once the mixture thickens and turns syrupy, mix in 1 tablespoon of lemon juice. For additional flavor, add in some lemon zest. Drizzle this icing over the top of your cake. Consider sprinkling some lemon zest over the top of the icing. Try an orange glacé icing. Combine 5 ounces (150 grams) of confectioners/icing sugar and 2 tablespoons of fresh-squeezed orange juice in a bowl. Mix briskly with a small whisk until you get a thick, syrupy mixture. If you want your glaze to be thinner, add some more orange juice. For additional flavor, add some orange zest. Drizzle the icing over the top of the cake. Consider sprinkling some orange zest over the icing. Try a spiced buttercream. In a mixing bowl, combine ¼ cup (55 grams) granulated sugar, ¼ cup (30 grams) confectioners/icing sugar, 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon, and ¼ teaspoon ground cloves. Set it aside. In a separate bowl, beat 2 cups (475 milliliters) whipping/heavy cream until stiff peaks form. Slowly mix in the sugar mixture and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract until you get a smooth color and consistency. Spread the buttercream over the cake once the cake cools. You can spread it over the top and the sides, or just the top. Try a cream cheese buttercream. In a mixing bowl, beat together 6 ounces (170 grams) of softened cream cheese and 1/3 cup (75 grams) of softened, unsalted butter. Slowly mix in 1¾ cups (220 grams) of confectioners/icing sugar and ½ teaspoon of vanilla extract. Keep mixing until the buttercream is light and fluffy. You can spread the buttercream over the top and the sides of your cake, or just the top. Consider sprinkling some candied orange peel, orange zest, or candied ginger bits over the buttercream once you are done. Consider making some sugared cranberries. Rinse and dry your cranberries, then coat them with a mixture made from 2 teaspoons of agave nectar and 1 teaspoon of water. Toss the berries in a bowl filled with ¼ cup (50 grams) granulated sugar. Gently lift the sugar-coated berries out of the bowl and let them dry on a sheet of parchment paper for 1 hour. Decorating the Cake Make sure that the cake is completely cool before you start decorating it. If you decorate it too soon, the icing will melt and slide right off. Also, a warm cake is a fragile cake. If you try to handle it too soon, it may fall apart. Listed below are several decorating ideas. Spread some buttercream over the top of the cake. For a richer cake, spread more buttercream down the sides. Use a spatula, palette knife, or butter knife to do this. Start spreading from the center outwards. You can make the frosting as smooth or as textured as you'd like. Fill the cake with buttercream or jam. Slice the cake in half horizontally. Spread some buttercream or over the bottom layer. Start from the center and work your way towards the ends. When you are done, place the upper layer on top. You can then spread more buttercream over the top and sides or the cake, or drizzle some glacé icing over it. Pour some glacé icing over the top of the cake. For some added color and flavor, sprinkle some lemon zest, orange zest, candied orange peel, or candied ginger over the top of your frosted cake. Make some sugared cranberries and arrange them on top of your cake. Cover your cake with thick, buttercream frosting first. Then, arrange the sugared cranberries however you want on top. To make the berries look like holly, add some mint leaves. Here is one decorating idea:
After you have frosted your cake, three berries in the center. Arrange rest all around the edges of the cake. Place two to three mint leaves around the three center berries. Add some mini gingerbread men on top of the cake. Begin by frosting your cake with a thick layer of buttercream. Make or buy some 1 to 2 inch (2.54 to 5.08 centimeters) tall gingerbread men. Stick them on top of a cake, right into the frosting. You can use plain gingerbread men, or decorate them with piped icing ahead of time. Finished.
